channel.title: Jira
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [SS-124] Prime Lenses
item.description:
Prime Lenses ideally which are may be Cinema or Macro lenses and ideally with OIS and Autofocus and huge aperture

  • Wide angle 24 mm for walking around and seeing more surroundings with camera within arms reach
  • 50mm for sitting at desk most natural with camera 6 feet away
  • 85mm for more flattering look from 8 - 10 feet away. 85mm is common for closeups and headshots

Distance and focal length both affect frame. 50mm at 5ft away shoots the same frame and same depth of field as 35mm at 3.5 ft away and 85mm at 8.5ft away and so on assuming we keep the aperture the same sensor type

Long Focal Length

Longer focal length is more blurred and brings background objects closer to subject and looks more natural. Blurred background singles out the subject.

Wide Angle

Emphasizes distance from background and emphasizes the character and gives a bigger perspective on the world around. Good if the room is small and can’t stand far back from subject. They have more depth of field if the distance is kept constant. If you adjust distance with focal length, the frame and the depth of field remain the same.

Aperture

  • Match the apertures of lenses o they can all be exposed similarly in multicam and no need to adjust lighting when switching lenses
  • Bigger aperture, lower number, is faster and better
  • Get the fastest available to shoot in lower light without high ISO graininess
  • Faster aperture is a shallower depth of field to isolate subject against blurry background

Distance

  • If the focal point is far away, then the depth of field will be larger, i.e., if you focus on a bird in a far away tree with a wide angle lens, you will still have a good size depth of field.

Miscellaneous

  • Cinema lenses are optimized for video and more likely to be color matched within a given series
  • Canon L series lenses are the top of their line https://www.canon-europe.com/lenses/l-series-ef-rf/

Canon RF Mount Choices with autofocus only

  • $639 Samyang AF 14mm f/2.8 RF Lens for Canon RF
  • $699 Rokinon AF 14mm f/2.8 RF Lens for Canon RF
  • $2,199 Canon RF 50mm f/1.2L USM Lens with autofocus

Canon RF Mount Choices with AF and IS

  • $449 Canon RF 35mm f/1.8 IS Macro STM Lens with Filters Kit
  • $599 Canon RF 85mm f/2 Macro IS STM Lens

Other Canon RF Mount Choices

  • $849 Venus Optics Laowa 15mm f/2 FE Zero-D Lens for Canon RF
  • $125 Meike MK-50mm f/1.7 Lens for Canon RF
  • $449 Lensbaby Velvet 56mm f/1.6 Lens for Canon RF
  • $679 Mitakon Zhongyi Speedmaster 50mm f/0.95 III Lens for Canon RF

item.title: [SS-111] Acquire and organize a Digital Asset Manager (DAM)
item.description:
Try Google Photos or Google Drive

  • Practice storing and retrieving 4K video. Google Photos has a setting called "original quality"
  • Try integration with Adobe CC
  • Harvard account has unlimited storage (find out if I will keep it post graduation)
  • Estimate storage and estimate pricing
  • Create a folder structure

Try Vimeo Pro plan for $20/month and 20GB/week and 1TB/year

Other options

  • Bynder
  • Kyno
  • Adobe Experience Manager (AEM)
  • axle.ai
  • pics.io

b. Hover shows contact card

c. Move help question marks to the roles

item.title: [SS-95] Second Camera for Multicam
item.description:
Buy cameras of same make and ideally model.

Film simultaneously with four cameras in 4K.

  1. Primary full frame camera straight on with widest angle lens
  2. Secondary camera on motorized “curved slider” at least 30 degrees from the Primary camera.
  3. Third Camera in high wide shot from top of closet at further distance and ideally 30 degrees from the secondary camera.
  4. Fourth camera overhead

Follow the five shot rule

  1. Medium shot From the waist up (Camera 1)
  2. Wide shot of full location (Camera 3)
  3. Detail close up (Camera 1 zoom crop)
  4. Long full body (Camera 2)
  5. Broll cut away (Primary Camera 1 used again)
  6. Overhead (Camera 4 is optional)

And get at least two takes of each angle especially the wide and close up. Can throw in low angle and POV shots

Reviewer Favorites

  • Sony A7s III
  • Sony ZV-1
  • Blackmagic cinema pocket 4K

Camera Combination Options

  • $11,500 Sony A7s III & A7r IV & 2 ZV1s (best video & best photo, and best vlogging)
  • $9,000 Sony A7r IV & 3 A7rIIs
  • $8,000 Canon EOS R5 & R6 & 2 M50s
  • $7,750 Sony A7sIII & 3 ZV1s
  • $6,750 Sony A7r IV & 3 ZV1s
  • $6,000 Three Blackmagic cinema pocket 4K and use existing 2 EF lenses and buy metabones speedboosters designed for the camera $500 each. Keep using M100 for thumbnails
  • $5,000 Canon EOS R6 & RP & 2 M50s
  • $5,000 Canon EOS R & 3 RPs
  • $4,000 Four Canon EOS RP
  • $3,700 Canon EOS R & 3 M50s
  • $3,200 Two Canon EOS RP and 2 M50s
  • $3,000 Four Sony ZV1
  • $2,700 Canon EOS RP & 3 M50s

item.title: [SS-88] See Scrum Downloadable Brochure
item.description:
Use Adobe InDesign to make a downloadable brochure. Leverage the YouTube channel art and the home page product description.

Include One Hundred Reasons to use See Scrum Highlight the patentable ideas:

  • Scrum Diagram Driver
  • Burndownchart with effort adjuster and capacity line
  • Sprint Planning IFA analytics
  • Velocity Chart with trend line and conclusion box
  • Unique integrations with Bitbucket and Sonar

Include Jira Gaps

  • Jira doesn’t fully model Scrum
    • No retrospective tool
    • No poker tool
    • No Daily Scrum tool, e.g., no place for minutes
    • No Showcase link to screen shots or video
  • No Scrum diagram
  • No Scrum Training, help, or tips
  • No Predictions and no chance to adjust effort o people. No check on story points and LOC done and ToDo
  • No Optimized pairings and teams, no identification of best lineups
  • No vacation handling for velocity. No unexpected OOO handling
  • Visualization not prominently integrated (stand alone section
  • Visualization not overly interactive
  • Jira introduces non-Scrum terminology like “issue type” to tag Epics. Cognitive overload
  • No velocity measurement and burn down in LOC as well as story points
  • No Sonar integration, i.e., no quality measaures
  • Manually maintained Jira stories become a proxy for the real code in Git
  • Jira has no AI because the manually maintained data isn’t good enough
  • No separation of internal vs external consumption view
  • No RAG rating for sprint or story or release
  • No team factors - team size, team location, employee/contractor, skillsets, on multiple teams, etc.
  • Complex learning curve
  • PRs don’t change the state
  • No critical path support for dependency linked stories
  • No sequencing of sprint stories, i.e., developer do story A first

item.title: [SS-57] Curved Slider
item.description:
2nd camera should be on the fill light side on a slider which is ideally curved and perhaps with 50mm lens. While sliding, simultaneously pan for the “paralax” effect. If the slider is curved, less, or no, panning is required. The 1st camera can be on slider too.

Moza

$800 Air Cross 2 and Slypod can simulate curved slider when combined with motorized tripod head (plus do tons more stuff)

Syrp Items

  • $1,814 Genie II 3-axis Indie kit which contains
    • $586 Genie mini II pan and tilt
    • $895 Genie II linear
    • $328.89 39' magic carpet medium track with carriage and end caps

Pro Media Gear Items

  • $799.95 VS368 PMG-DUO 36 Inch Interview Video Slider (96 inch curve)
  • $59.95 CS60 Slider Clamp
  • $549.95 VSMDC1 Motor and controller
  • $39.95 VSCL PMG Duo Slider Limit Clamps SET OF 2

item.title: [SS-56] Tripod with motorized head
item.description:
Need to make slypod emulate a curved slider by panning the slypod. By tilting the slypod, we can even raise the camera level.

$250 Bescor MP-PRO Motorized Pan & Tilt Head Total Package Kit

Light should be as close as possible to be softer.

item.title: [SS-49] Primary Camera
item.description:
Position slightly below eye level looking straight on

Criteria:

  • 4K video
  • Mike input
  • IBIS
  • Flip out screen
  • Get a zoom lens with approximately 24 -70mm range

Upgrade from a Canon M100 to one of the following.

  1. Sony A7siii (2020 $5,496, 4K120, 12MP, no recording limit, IBIS, 2 card slots, weather sealed, ISO 102,000 extended to 496,000, video optimized camera)
  2. Sony A9 ($5,496, 4K30fps, 24MP ISO ISO 100 - 51200 and extended to 204800, IBIS Weather Sealed)
  3. Canon EOS R5 (2020 $4,999, 8K, 4K 120FPS, 42MP, ISO 50K up to 100K, IBIS Weather Sealed, more stills oriented but trying to be perfect hybrid)
  4. Sony A7R iv (sep 2019, $4,296, 61mp, 4K30fps, ISO 32,000, IBIS weather sealed)
  5. Nikon Z7(2018 $3,446, 45mp weather sealed, IBIS 4k 30FPS full frame)
  6. Sony A7r iii (oct 2017, $2,896, 42MP, IBIS, weather sealed, dual card slots, full frame 4K 30FPS, includes mic)
  7. Canon EOS R6 ($2,800, 20MP, 4K 60FPS, kit lens OIS, IBIS, Weather sealed, ISO 102,000 to 204,000, 2 SD cards )
  8. Sony A7s ii (2015, $2,696, with lens and mic and accessories, full frame, 12MP, 4K30, ISO expanded to 409,000, IBIS)
  9. Nikon Z6 (2018 $2,446 with Kit Lens, 24mp, weather sealed and IBIS 2020, 4K 30FPS, full frame video, 1 SD card)
  10. Fuji Film XT-4 (May 2020, $2,100, 26MP, 4K 60 FPS, ISO 12,800, IBIS, and kit lens with OIS, ASC, great sensor which turns over, weather sealed)
  11. Canon EOS R (2018, $2,099, 30MP 4K30fps, kit lens, no IBIS, weather sealed, ISO 40,000)
  12. Sony A7 III ($1,999 with kit lens, 24mp, ISO 51,200, IBIS, 4K full frame 30 FPS, weather sealed)
  13. Sony A7rII (2015, $1,598 with kit lens, 42mp, IBIS, 4K at 30 FPS, full frame, ISO 102,000, weather sealed)
  14. Nikon Z5 (2020 $1395 with kit lens, 24mp, weather sealed and IBIS 2020, 1.7x crop factor on 4K video, no slo mo)
  15. Canon EOS RP (2019 $1,299 with kit lens 26MP 4K30fps)
  16. Nikon Z50 (oct 2019, $896, 20MP, 4K30fps, No IBIS, ISO 51,200)
  17. Sony A7 II ($1,000 with kit lens, 24mp, IBIS, 2K video))
  18. Sony ZV 1 (May 2020 $748 with kit lens 4k30fps not cropped, tons of vlogger friendly features, 20MP, ISO 12,800, IBIS, skin softening, in camera ND, single built in lens with lens stabilization ) Must have super buy is the “easy to hold grip” with vlogger kit
  19. Canon M50 (april 2018, $579, 24MP, 4K24, ISO 25,600, digital images stabilization, body only and use EF-M lenses from M100)

item.title: [SS-25] Retrospective Chart
item.description:
Create a retrospective chart with the following features:

  • Selector for time period, exclude outliers
  • FA icons scatter plot of happy/sad faces
  • Large FA icon and bottom line conclusion box

item.title: [SS-24] Sprint Burn Down Chart
item.description:
Burndown chart with the following features:

  • Lines for Capacity (avg. velocity weighted toward most recent), Committed, and Actual
  • Actual line extrapolation predictor
  • Effort adjuster slider to change % effort and see the extrapolation line change
  • Button to automatically set the % effort required
  • Bottom line conclusion box – At this rate you will finish 2 days late. It will take 10% more effort to complete on time
  • View by story points, hours, and stories

item.title: [SS-23] Velocity Chart
item.description:
Velocity chart which includes the following:

  • Autosize to fit in area below the Scrum Diagram
  • Use object model which leverages classes for at least a bar chart and an SVG class
  • Committed and completed with a big trend line going to a box with the insight. The insight should include a Reliability Index which equals 100 * (completed/committed)
  • RAG colored bands to show velocity outliers
  • Measure by
    • Story Points (Default)
    • Hours
    • Stories
    • LOC
    • Pull Requests
    • Jira Releases
  • Selectors for
    • time period
    • include/exclude outlier sprints
    • include/exclude sprints with the same team members
    • versus same time last year

item.title: [SS-22] Scrum Process Diagram
item.description:
Create a Scrum Process Diagram which includes:

  • The Scrum Artifacts (Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, Product Increment)
  • The Scrum Ceremonies (Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, and Sprint Showcase, and Sprint Retrospective)
  • The Scrum Roles (Product Owner, Scrum Master, and Team Member)
  • Links to Just In Time training for each artifact, ceremony, and role
  • Links to project visualizations such as the velocity chart, burn down chart, and retrospective chart.
  • Sprint Metrics values (Backlog story count, Sprint Planning IFAs, Sprint backlog story points, etc.)

item.title: [SS-21] Extract SonarQube Data
item.description: Extract SonarQube data to a csv file suitable for ingestion and analysis by the See Scrum application.

item.title: [SS-20] Create a SonarQube Project
item.description: Purchase a SonarQube license and set up a project pointing at the Git source code repository of See Scrum

item.title: [SS-19] Create a SonarQube project for See Scrum
item.description: Create a SonarQube project and set it up to scan the Git source code repository for See Scrum and generate coding flaws and security issues. Export the data for ingestion and analysis by the See Scrum application.
item.summary: Create a SonarQube project for See Scrum

item.title: [SS-18] Create a retrospective tool
item.description:
Create a retrospective tool to record the teams ideas of things to:

  • start doing
  • stop doing
  • keep doing
  • Log Scores in categories

item.title: [SS-14] Create a Git Project for See Scrum
item.description:
• Create a Git project to maintain the source code for See Scrum.
  • Back up See Scrum project
  • Validate that development and pull request round trip works for the web project
  • Add the python server to the git repo
  • Rename ScrumSee to SeeScrum
  • Merge develop branch into master after a full test

GET LATEST
git checkout develop
git fetch origin
git pull origin develop

MAKE A CHANGE
git branch my-chart
git checkout my-chart
git status
Develop changes

CHECK IN THE CHANGE
git add .
git commit -m 'feat: my chart'
git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git merge --no-ff my-chart
git push origin develop

DISCARD LOCAL CHANGES

git fetch --all
git reset --hard origin/develop

Merge develop BRANCH TO master

(on branch development)$ git merge master
(resolve any merge conflicts if there are any)
git checkout master 
git merge development
git push -u origin master
item.summary: Create a Git Project for See Scrum

item.title: [SS-13] Extract a Jira Data File
item.description:
Export data from Jira into a CSV file suitable for ingestion by the See Scrum application. This is a first step toward automated integration via web service.

Follow these step which created the attached csv:

  1. select Issues in left hand Nav
  2. select Advanced Search on right near Top
  3. select Switch to JQL link at right of the query fields
  4. Verify that the JQL displays all fields like this: project = "SS" ORDER BY created DESC
  5. Select Export at Top right
  6. Select Export XML
  7. Convert to json

item.title: [SS-12] Add Jira Stories
item.description: Write all the stories required to reach a mature product stage which is ready for public consumption and assign them to epics, sprints and releases.

item.title: [SS-11] Create a Jira Project
item.description:
Create a Jira Project:

  • Create a project with a Scrum template
  • Create custom fields for Scrum story templates
  • Create Sprints and Epics

item.description:
• Tutorial videos
  • Product videos
  • Scrum blog
  • About info
